snippet: Robert Stone, who died on Saturday at 77, explored the underside of American life in books populated with pilgrims, agitators and crackpots in search of salvation, or what he called “the numinous.”
abstract: Michiko Kakutani An Appraisal column on Robert Stone, writer whose novels capture counterculture zeal, rising nihilism and apocalyptic madness of the 1960s and 1970s.
lead_paragraph: Robert Stone, who died on Saturday at 77, explored the underside of American life in books populated with pilgrims, agitators and crackpots in search of salvation, or what he called “the numinous.”

headline.print_headline: A Chronicler of an America Without a Path
headline.seo: In Robert Stone’s Books, Heroes, Hedonism and Old-Fashioned Moralism
headline.main: A Chronicler of an America Without a Path
